H0.text: It increases the rate of the reaction when the temperature of the reactants is increased.

H1.text: It patterns it how increasing the temperature of reactants affects the rate of their reaction.

H2.text: It is unchanged is the effect on the rate of a reaction when the temperature of the reactants is increased.

H3.text: It decreases the rate of the reaction when the temperature of reactants is increased.

A4.text: However, the main reason that temperature increases the rate of reaction is that more of the colliding particles will have the necessary activation energy resulting in more successful collisions (when bonds are formed between reactants).

A5.text: Reactions without an activation barrier (for example, some radical reactions), tend to have anti-Arrhenius temperature dependence: the rate constant decreases with increasing temperature.

A6.text: With this equation it can be roughly estimated that the rate of reaction increases by a factor of about 2 to 3 for every 10 Â°C rise in temperature, for common values of activation energy and temperature range.

A7.text: It can be seen that either increasing the temperature or decreasing the activation energy (for example through the use of catalysts) will result in an increase in rate of reaction.
